meta.title: Seasonal Influenza (Flu) – Structured Descriptive Dataset
sources: World Health Organization (WHO) seasonal influenza fact sheet
US CDC – Signs and Symptoms of Flu
US CDC – People at Increased Risk of Flu Complications
Canada Public Health – Flu (Influenza) symptoms and treatment

overview.what_is_flu: Seasonal influenza (flu) is an acute respiratory infection caused mainly by influenza A and B viruses. The virus infects the nose, throat and sometimes the lungs, leading to illness that can range from mild to severe and, in some cases, death.
key_points: Flu spreads easily between people via respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs, sneezes, talks, or through contact with contaminated surfaces followed by touching the nose, mouth or eyes.
Flu seasons occur every year and can cause large numbers of illnesses, hospitalizations, and deaths worldwide.
Most healthy people recover in less than two weeks, but some develop serious complications such as pneumonia.

symptoms.typical_onset: Symptoms usually begin suddenly, often within 1–4 days after infection.
gastrointestinal_symptoms: Diarrhea (more common in children than adults)
children_specific_notes: Children may show irritability, poor feeding, and low activity.
Ear pain, vomiting and diarrhea are more commonly reported in children with flu than in adults.

course_and_contagiousness.incubation_period: Typically 1–4 days from infection to symptom onset.
course_and_contagiousness.contagious_period: Most people are contagious from about 1 day before symptoms start and for up to 5–7 days after becoming sick. Children and people with weakened immune systems may be contagious for longer.
course_and_contagiousness.illness_duration: Uncomplicated flu illness generally improves within a few days to less than two weeks, although cough and tiredness can last longer.

high_risk_groups.description: Certain groups are more likely to develop severe illness or complications from flu infection.
groups: Children younger than 5 years, especially those younger than 2 years
Pregnant people and those up to two weeks postpartum
People with chronic medical conditions such as asthma, COPD or other lung diseases
People with heart disease or history of stroke
People with diabetes or other metabolic disorders
People with kidney or liver disease
People with neurologic or neurodevelopmental conditions
People with blood disorders such as sickle cell disease
People with weakened immune systems due to disease or medication
People with obesity (high body mass index)
Residents of nursing homes and other long-term care facilities
Health-care workers and caregivers who may be frequently exposed

common_complications: Bronchitis (inflammation of the airways in the lungs)
Worsening of chronic conditions such as asthma or heart disease
severe_potential_complications: Inflammation of the brain (encephalitis) or muscles (myositis)

adults: Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath
Pain or pressure in the chest or abdomen
Sudden dizziness, confusion, or difficulty waking up
Symptoms that improve but then return with fever and worse cough
Signs of dehydration such as very little urine, very dry mouth or feeling extremely weak
children: Bluish or gray skin color (including lips)
Not drinking enough fluids or not making tears when crying
Not waking up or not interacting
Being so irritable that the child does not want to be held
Flu-like symptoms that improve but then return with worse cough or high fever
Any fever in an infant younger than 3 months
red_flag_and_emergency_signs.advice: Anyone with these warning signs should seek urgent medical care or go to the emergency department immediately.

vaccination.description: Annual flu vaccination is the most effective way to reduce the risk of getting flu and severe outcomes.
recommended_groups: Everyone aged 6 months and older, unless contraindicated
People at high risk of complications and their close contacts
Health-care workers, caregivers, and people who live with or care for high-risk individuals

personal_measures: Wash hands regularly with soap and water or use alcohol-based hand rubs.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick when possible.
Cover coughs and sneezes with a tissue or the elbow, not hands.
Avoid touching the face, especially eyes, nose and mouth.
Stay home from work, school or public places when sick.
Improve indoor ventilation and, in some settings, consider wearing a mask during peak flu season.

home_management: Rest and drink plenty of fluids.
Use over-the-counter medicines such as pain relievers and fever reducers as appropriate and according to local guidance.
Avoid giving aspirin to children and teenagers due to the risk of Reye’s syndrome.
Monitor for warning signs that symptoms are worsening or complications are developing.
self_care_and_basic_treatment.antiviral_medicines_note: In higher-risk patients and some others, health professionals may prescribe antiviral medicines which work best when started soon after symptom onset. Decisions about antivirals should always be made by a qualified health-care provider.

routine_medical_review: If flu-like symptoms are severe or not improving after several days.
If a person is in a high-risk group and develops flu-like symptoms.
If there is uncertainty whether the illness is flu or another condition.
emergency_care: Any of the red-flag signs listed above in adults or children.
Sudden confusion, difficulty speaking, or weakness on one side of the body.
Signs of breathing distress or chest pain.
Very high or persistent fever that does not respond to medication.
